bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, April 29, 1940

div1.p: Hench refers to his visit to Cuba and the presumed site of Camp Lazear on Rojas' family's farm. He comments on her recollections of Camp Lazear and the yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, April 29, 1940
div1.opener:
Yellow fever
April 29, 1940
Senora Maria Teresa Loma Viuda de Rojas
Calle 17 #207
Vedado, Habana
Cuba
My dear Senora Rojas:
div1.p:
I want to thank you again for the great kindness which you and your family
showed to me during my recent Habana visit. My wife and I were both very touched
and pleased at the lovely gift of flowers which you sent to our plane. It especially
thrilled Mrs. Hench as she had never been so overwhelmed by having as many as eight
gardenias at one time before. Our return flight was lovely, but on arrival home, I
found much work waiting for me and almost immediately a large medical convention also
opened in our town and I had house guests. In the middle of that, our nine-year old
boy developed acute appendicitis and was operated on, but is getting along nicely.

I am enclosing a number of photographs which I thought you would like to have,
and if you would like any more copies, please do not hesitate to ask for as many as you
wish. I shall be delighted to give them to you. I had a professional photographer take
two or three pictures of the old Rojas farm near the quarry but I want him to take three
or four more and will arrange this through Mr. Moran. No need not bother you in the
slightest about this. As

As I believe you know, I gave Mr. Pogolotti the two maps of the Rojas farm
and he is having copies made for me. If you do not receive these within a couple of
weeks I wish you would either write to me or call Mr. Pogolotti or Mr. Moran. I must
see to it that these are returned to you safely, and I am sure they will be.

I have not yet had time to have typed your statements and those of your niece
regarding the camp. I will have them typed and send you copies that you may return them
and verify them. At that time, I should be very grateful if you would add a brief para-
graph on the history of your farm, or anything pertaining to it and to the incident of
the yellow fever experiments that you may have remembered since I saw you. I have asked
Mr. Moran to see if he can find the name of some tree expert who might view and certify as to
the approximate ages of the Framboyant tree by the shacks on the San Jose farm, and also
identify the other three or four trees by these same shacks. I believe I gave Miss Cabrera
one of the leaves of the other tree. Perhaps she knows some tree expert who could do
this for me. I should be glad to pay him a small fee and will send him photographs of
the trees that I wish identified as to age and type.

I mentioned also to Miss Cabrera my desire to see some Habana newspapers which
had articles on the work at Camp Lazear, but I never did get into the library, as it was
closed when I went there. I think you and your family may be interested in one of these
newspapers (I don't know the name) of November 21, 1900. In that paper was launched a
storm of criticism against Reed's idea of human experiments at Camp Lazear. In as much as
- 2 -
Camp Lazear was on your property, doubtlessly you will be interested to read of that
historical occasion. I have asked Mr. Moran to look over the newspapers in the
Bibliotece de la Socieded Economica Dragones, but thought your daughter and Miss Cabrera
might like to see that paper sometime also.

I am preparing a report to give to the President of Washington and Jefferson
College, and I have been also asked by Dr. Ramos, Secretary of Defense of Cuba, to give
him a full report, establishing the claims for your San Jose farm as the true site of
Camp Lazear. I am also sending a copy to the United States Army Museum in Washington,
D. C. and will try to get some copies of the old photographs in Camp Lazear, takin in
1900--the ones I showed to you. I am sure you would like to have these and I think you
and your family should have these in your possession.

I shall take the liberty of writing you further from time to time as matters
progress. I may be required to call on you for further information and help in order to
establish proof that Camp Lazear was really on your property, and I am sure that your
family ought to have this recognition. I left a little sum of money with Mr. Moran
and you may find it more convenient to dictate some data to send to me from time to
time than to write it out. If so, I shall be glad to pay the expenses of a stenographer.
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips, Manzana de Gomez 553, did some secretarial work for me and should
you care to use her services, please do so and have her send me the bill.

I cannot thank you enough for all the courtesies which you and your family
showed me. It was delightful to meet you, and I hope we may meet again soon, perhaps
sometime in the United States; if not, again in Cuba.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
